subject: Law
title: Work for Hire: Who Owns What You Create at Work
description: A micro-lesson that makes Work for Hire: Who Owns What You Create at Work usable.

hook.text: You wrote a brilliant report for your employer. You created itâ€”but they own the copyright.

buildup.text: Under the work-for-hire doctrine, the employer owns the copyright when an employee creates work within their job scope.

discovery.text: For contractors, it's different. Work is only 'for hire' with a written agreement and specific categories.

twist.text: Many freelancers don't know this. Without a contract, they own what they createâ€”even if the client paid for it.

climax.text: The distinction between employee and contractor is crucial. Courts use multiple factors to decide.

punchline.text: Who owns the work depends on who you are, not just who paid.

quiz.question: Under work for hire, who owns an employee's creation?
